Award.AwardTitle: Diachronic Generative Syntax Conference XIII: Support for meeting and associated workshop

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports a workshop and conference in the annual international series "Conference on Diachronic Generative Syntax" (DIGS). Researchers in the field of diachronic syntax study language change from three perspectives: Firstly, they attempt to specify the grammatical properties of languages spoken in the past, combining knowledge of grammatical theory gleaned from work on modern languages with the study of historical materials. Secondly, they aim to develop an understanding of the conditions under which languages change rather than remaining stable. Both language contact and instabilities in language transmission are investigated in this regard. Finally, researchers study the time course of language change, using statistical techniques to track changes over time in the usage frequencies of grammatical elements. The time course of change can then be modeled mathematically, using techniques from epidemiology and population biology.

This is the thirteenth meeting of DIGS Conference, whose venue alternates between the eastern and western hemispheres. This year's meeting is distinguished from others by the addition of a pre-conference workshop on the use of syntactically annotated corpora for historical research. The growing use of highly annotated corpora in diachronic syntax is a part of an ongoing revolution in the sciences of language made possible by modern computational technology and techniques of language engineering.

DIGS meetings feature plenary addresses by the most distinguished scholars in the field of language history and presentations by established researchers and students. In addition, there is a poster session for the best papers that cannot be accommodated in main conference sessions. Funds are included in the grant budget to subsidize travel to the conference by student presenters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award helped to fund the 13th meeting of the Diachronic Generative Syntax Conference (DiGS), an international conference held every year, alternating between the Americas and Europe. Diachronic generative syntax is the field that uses the concepts and principles of modern grammatical theory to study the history of languages with a substantial surviving textual record, investigating both how their grammars have changed over time and how the diffusion of changes is documented in the surviving corpora of texts.

The 13th DiGS meeting was held in Philadelphia, at the University of Pennsylvania, and was hosted by the University's Department of Linguistics. The conference took place over four days and featured 68 presenters from 14 countries. A particular emphasis of the 13th meeting was the use of the growing number of grammatically annotated electronic corpora of historical texts to carry out both grammatical and statistical analyses of older languages and to describe the time course of changes in their word forms and word order.

The study of language history through electronic corpora is a new discipline, made possible by the increasing power of modern computational technology. This technology allows investigators to search for complex grammatical properties of texts, tabulating both their frequencies and their co-occurrence relationships. The technology undergirds both the construction of corpora, which depends crucially on recent advances in Natural Language Processing, and the search algorithms used to extract data from them. With the increasing amount corpus data being produced, investigators are now able to develop and test both formal and statistical models of language structure and changes in it. In doing so, they use modern mathematical results and techniques developed over the course of the twentieth century, which have come to be widely used in fields from biology to computer science, as well as other disciplines.

The NSF award explicitly provided funds for the conference organizers to run an all-day workshop on the construction and use of annotated corpora, focusing on the corpora of English that have been constructed over the past two decades at the University of Pennsylvania, largely with NSF funding. These corpora are documented at the following website:

www.ling.upenn.edu/histcorpora/

The program of DiGS 13, including abstracts of the presentations, is available at:

www.ling.upenn.edu/Events/DIGS13/
